comments.commentBody: No surprise here that again the Obama administration left a mess.  Now it might be one of the larger foreign issues, but jobs and the economy are far more important.  Of course you can't stop countries that want nuclear weapons and will spend the money to get them, unless you use force.  One of the proper responses to them is to have great defense against their capability.  With those who are not rational MAD is not an effective deterrent.
It's only a matter of time before democrats dream up some North Korean conspiracy story.  Like the Russian hacking, this is Obama's mess left for Trump to clean up.
FACTS not fiction please. Obama , through quiet diplomacy has kept the Americans safer  than we has been for some years.....

Arriving at a peaceable solution to this crisis will require artful negotation.  But we have a "serially mendacious" POTUS whose reputation for going back on his word precedes him, whether it's shamelessly stiffing his building contractors or shrugging off guarantees to share his tax returns.  How can we expect Trump to  build alliances and forge agreements with world leaders when he's proven repeatedly that he places zero stock in delivering on his promises?

One insane "leader" threatens another with a slapped wrist if he launches a nuclear missile at us. He does not fear mutually assured destruction because he has already destroyed his country. Now he wants to do the same to us. But, one missile, even 5 will not destroy us. No matter where they hit. Americans will die, cities lost. It would be awful. But, enough would be left to keep going. Unlike us carpet bombing N.Korea with small tactical nukes (fairly soon to expire anyway). One nuke launches. N.Korea destroyed. Now, do Americans still have the balls to do that? I am, sadly, no longer sure. We won't even fight for our own country. Let alone to protect the world.
Fill B-1 Bombers with both all our tactical nukes, & old fashioned HE & Thermo bombs, Keep airborne near enough to N.Korea, that they will know that if they launch even one more test missile, we will obliterate them. Of course telling China that this is in their defense also, as the closest world power to N.Korea. Suggesting they do the same (bombers loaded & ready). So N.Korea would be gone before one small missile from them has had time to travel here. We could still use our 56% successful deterrent. So, better than even chance it wouldn't ever hit us anyway. (While working to improve the system. That military money should be spent. Making what we have better, not buying more of the not quite so good.)

Who poses a greater nuclear threat? Kim Jong-un, or Donald Trump? My suggestion is to consider what  the time would be set to on the Doomsday Clock, were either one to be removed from power. Trump's election to office has placed us closer to midnight than it's been since 1953. Once again, perhaps we ought to listen to the scientists.

Given his latest tweet storm, we must seriously consider that Trump is mentally ill or in the early stages of dementia and remedy the situation.  The deadly serious nature of the North Korea nuclear threat demands nothing less.

I have no doubt California will survive intact.

After all, Californian residents are convinced that the Russians are the greater threat, and I agree!

Ever since that wonderful Hollywood movie, "The Russians are Coming," I know that the Russians are probably landing by submarine and the coastal bunkers from WWII will come in handy.

About North Korea's ICBMs, stop the hysteria. We made the same deal with them as we made with Iran, and the Iran deal is agreed by all to be a "game changer," and to have "prevented war" with stringent controls and the off-loading of nuclear material. Ya see, nothing to worry about!

Anyway, if the N.Koreans ever did launch toward LA, they could not pass the stringent local emissions standards and their rockets would not be permitted.

"(1) assist in dealing with the refugee crisis that will ensue in the aftermath of what is likely to be a chaotic reunification process,"

You're showing your hand in what you think the "reunification process" should look like. If the re-unification process were truly democratic then the only group of refugees would be Kim Jong-un and his crew. However it sounds like you have more of a "worker state" solution in mind.

"(2) terminate our defense treaty with the South and withdraw our troops post-reunification, allowing the South to become non-aligned."

Who decides the re-unification process has been completed as agreed? If by whatever process is used there is no consensus the process is completed while you be among the chorus to call for US troop removal regardless?

Please, no arguments about China being too closely tethered to S. Korean business and how it wouldn't make sense for for China to take one course of action or another. China is going to do what it wants, when it wants whether the actions are driven by business interests, nationalistic feelings or owning their backyard.

We should send cruise missiles to destroy the boat on which Kim Jong-un is observing his next missile test. Following Kim's death, the North Koreans likely would be obsessed with the issue of succession above all other matters of state, including retaliation. Eliminating Kim may pose a risk of renewed war on the Korean peninsula, but I think the risk is relatively small, and we have to do something to stop North Korea from developing an ICBM capable of striking the U.S. with a nuclear weapon.

comments.userLocation: Way Out West between Broadway and Philadelphia
comments.commentBody:
North Korea should be taken out, in a pre-emptive "decapitation attack." That term in quotation marks was part of the deterrence-theory lexicon back in the days of the U.S-Soviet arms race. Would China launch against the U.S in retaliation? That would hardly be a realistic option for China, and the leaders of China know it.

Then, when the destruction of North Korea is an accomplished fact, impeach Trump for some other reason -- there are certainly enough of them. No, I am not being facetious. My approach to policy questions has always been "pick-and-choose." I consider North Korea an annoyance, and I also consider ideological and social conservatism an annoyance. I would possibly be a Libertarian if there were a Marxist variety of Libertarians, but, unfortunately, those folks are ideologically stuck in the 18th century.

The thought of such a thoughtless numbskull as Trump Von Clownstick having to deal with the evil of North Korea only makes me more incredulous how so many millions of White Americans could have voted for such an ignoramus as Trump to represent US in making these cataclysmic choices. Trump and his Reich Fuhrer SS Bannon are just itching to pull the trigger and create a nuclear holocaust. Their threats are backed up by a nationalistic psychosis both of the share. Their sense of machismo at all costs and preservation of manhood is paramount. God help US, and even that may not be enough. Thanks Trumpets for bringing US such Evil.

DD
Manhattan

Obviously, when Obama advised Trump that this may be his most pressing challenge, he had no way of knowing that Arnold would be leaving The Apprentice and that would take up a lot of the president's time.  We have a clueless adolescent making planet-altering decisions.  I hope that some of his more level-headed advisers can succeed in getting him to bow to their wisdom.  So far, not much sign of that happening.

The comments highlighting China's desire for a buffer between themselves and US troops in South Korea is most likely outdated. The time for speculation about China's motivations are long past. We should assume that US negotiators ask China directly for terms that would lead to China's total dedication to regime change in North Korea, and this if China had a deal in mind that met out criteria, we would have pursued it.

What this mean is that the US must pressure China to participate in a comprehensive solution, and for there to be repurcussions if they do not. Although these types of hard line policies are to be avoided, due to the risks inherent, it appears that the time has finally come to end the North Korean threat once and, hopefully, for all time.

Trump is our Tweeter in Chief. When it comes to writing hostile tweets, he's the best. Dealing with the complex problems of the real world is another matter altogether.

It's not clear that Trump has the intellect or the temperament to seek the advice of experts, and to be able to understand and act on their recommendations. He consistently demeans experts by dismissing them as the "elite."

Trump himself is the biggest single threat to our national security. We are also endangered by his supporters, who place partisanship above patriotism.

Trump needs to be removed from office as quickly as possible.

At this juncture, fraught with uncertainty and danger, we have exactly the wrong man leading our government.  One recalls the deft President Kennedy, overruling  his own military, who calling for a strike against the Soviets in Cuba and on the seas, and enabling direct contact with Khrushchev.  He then gave him a way out of the impasse by removing the obsolete IRBMs from Turkey, allowing the Soviet leader to silence his own hardliners.  In a coming confrontation with North Korea, Trump might stupidly light a match that ignites a nuclear conflagration.
But the Cuba/Russia crisis was resolved because 2 SANE leaders were able to negotiate......Trump & Kim Jong-un.......not so good!

Kim has shown he is dangerously ruthless. His international warfare threat is immediate not only to the United States but to other perceived enemies. He has no qualms in acting with impunity against any domestic threats. He murders his own people on a regular basis regardless of their station and he will do this anywhere. The fact that he moves against his most trusted military officers is what concerns me the most.
Next to North Korea he believes the United States is his most powerful adversary and is liable to strike out pre-emptively against us. He may feel that we are especially vulnerable right now considering the complete chaos in the White House. With president Trump sending out his misguided tweets he Is liable to precipitate a strike from North Korea. Kim is as unhinged as our president and neither can be trusted.
I have faith in the generals he has appointed to his NSC and pray they have the intelligence to do the right thing. Let's hope that our president will do what they recommend.

More and more, the American public is coming to believe that Donald Trump is the "Baby Huey" of Presidential Mistakes of all time, -- and that the American Republican Organization is the most evil and dishonest organization on the planet. I guess the "slowness" and the "phoniness" is "staged" because huge profist are being made by all. I do not "believe" that Trump has the real Nuclear Codes and that, at this time, the "Twitter Tweeter in the White House," has no real  authority or power over anything or anyone. He and Bannon are not "in charge" and who is in charge is all being handled "Back-of-House" at the Pentagon and on The Hill which is exactly why no  one is doing anything quickly enough, once again. I do believe that the groundswell of resistance from the American people should scare the Republicans, though, because Americans are beyond sick and tired of the Republicans, and every Republican knows to be making early retirement plans or planning new careers by 2018 and 2020.

In its efforts to create controversy and manufacture scandal for the Trump administration (because he's the boogeyman), the Times will cast ethics and public safety to the wind in order to report any leak of strategy or information that might appease its meme hungry liberal base. Such appeasement to the potential cost of nuclear destruction of Manhattan for a few clicks and the desperation of a Pulitzer is hardly investigative. It's terrifying.
Right on, a true reading of our NYT today!

Readers may ask why the NYT published what appears to be classified information that should have been kept secret. The Times needs to answer that question, but let me offer several sensible answers.

1) North Koreans know we are conducting "left of launch" cyber strikes so the American public ought to know, in general terms, what the U.S. is doing to protect us from a DPRK nuke attack.

2) The story, at the request of the USG, was scrubbed of details that might give the DPRK insight into how to defeat our disruption of their missiles.

3) Inasmuch as much as both the Obama and Trump administrations have provided input into this story in response to the Time's Inquiries, readers may reasonably conclude that our government (old and new) thinks it's good to have this information on the public record.

Where the story breaks down is the inadequate discussion, except for pointing out the DPRK holds Seoul hostage to a rain of northern missiles, of the terrible risks involved in preemptive war (aka, the Bush Doctrine). In Iraq, thousands of Americans and 100s of thousands of Iraqis died in a war fought under false pretenses. A war which we are still fighting (now against ISIS).

Arguably, the U.S. needs to a return to a doctrine that served the Republic well for most of it lifetime, that of Self-Defense, of itself and allies.

The power grid. Southern California is vulnerable to a loss of electrical power because there are two transmission lines, one from the north and the other from the east. Both traverse many miles of desolate terrain and it would not be difficult to take down several towers. Repairs would require crews, their food, shelter, lodging, gas and diesel fuel, more.
To the west, the Pacific Ocean and Mexico to the south.

This situation is so much more complex than I had imagined, it is truly terrifying that this should be in the hands of such an incompetent and trigger-happy administration. Diplomacy needs to be left to diplomats (of which the president should be the most qualified), not blow-hards and ideologues.

No doubt, I should feel grateful that I am living in Mexico rather than the U.S., but much of my heart remains in the U.S., and in case, whatever the outcome of this sticky situation, the ramifications will affect the whole world.

And I won't even open the topic of the effect of #45's upcoming policies on Mexico. Suffice it to say, this administration has left the whole world quaking, and now, in light of the Korea situation, we all should be quaking. Where's Obama when we need him?

Wolfie...if you remove the suggestion of arms and execution, I would be inclined to agree with you.  However, your introduction of violence into the mix takes us exactly to the same place that most reasonable Americans would attribute to the very menace that we are trying to neutralize. Protest, resist, investigate, and use our courts and other legal pathways to achieve our goals without destroying our values and democracy in the process.

Donald Trump doesn't have the intellectual or emotional maturity to govern. Likewise, many of the people he's put in place around him are equally incapable (unfit, unqualified, unprepared and inexperienced) to lead our foreign or domestic policy. Even as a puppet regime under Russia, our ability to deal with N. Korea (as well as China and just about everywhere else) has plummeted.

If congress (meaning the impotent, majority republicans) do not act and act soon to change this, there will be little we can do to undo the damage done by this severely misguided shambles of an administration. This is a clear and present danger to the US. And the saddest truth is: the pentagon will now, more than ever, essentially be running our government. We're a second world military state. Led by a puppet. Who happens to be an imbecile.

Very dangerous times indeed.

Fact is, Pres. Trump is not responsible for the situation re North Korea.  Nor is Trump responsible for Syria, Ukraine, Libya, Yemen, etc. and the cold war with Russia.  Your criticism should be directed to the past Administrations.

No matter what he inherited from past administrations, he is responsible for everything that happens from day one of his own. However he moves forward, it is obviously his responsibility. That he has colluded with the Russians, that he pathologically lies, that he has absolutely no understanding of our foreign or domestic policies and no interest in learning, that he is simply signing whatever is put before him by Bannon and others, that he is bilking the taxpayers like no other president before him and that he continues to work tirelessly on his own business ventures (again, Russia)--all of that is his responsibility. He's a disaster for the American people.

DPRK for years has called for bilateral relations with the US. It seems the time has come for that. In addition, diplomacy is progressive, cyberattacks and posturing is primitive. Also few Americans have been told about the destruction of the north during the Korean War. It remains one of the most untold stories of strategic bombing in the history of warfare. DPRK has not forgotten the devastation wrought by US airpower.

Why why why...

If we can develop highly complex cyber weapons systems and anti ballistic missile systems, why cant we combine those technologies with assassination of Kim? And we should not act alone, rather gather the help of the nations Kim threatens, the free democratic world.

We should spend much more money on Espionage and it should be used vigorously.

I'm puzzled with the assumption that North Korea will stage a nuclear attack on the US with missiles.  It would seem more likely that they would use an alternate delivery mechanism ... for example a shipping container.  Yes, some shipping containers are scanned, but certainly not all.
